title: How do I discredit a witness for a large credit card company that is going to testify about my cc debt?
question: Does anyone have any questions that can be used at trial to discredit the 'keeper of records'.
answers:
The art of cross-examination is not an easy one! Lawyers spend years in court developing this technique. First you need to examine the background of the witness? Have they been convicted of a felony involving moral turpitude, have they been fired from a job, if so, why, etc.
Do they have a mental defect that would make them unreliable, are they on medication, drugs, etc.
Are they able to establish sufficient background or experience to be able to competently testify? How long were they at the company, do they work in the department involved, etc.?
Then you need to look at the reliability of their testimony, is it hearsay, or otherwise unreliable, if they are using documents, can they establish a proper foundation for the documents, etc.
Do they have any motive to lie, were they pressured by their superior to testify in a certain way, are they up for a promotion, etc.

What evidence do you have that the witness is not trustworthy?
What evidence do you have that the copies are not duplicates of the originals?
And what is your definition of an original? (a computer printed statement can be reprinted)

Do you not qualify for BK? or are you planning on going to law school and just want to get some first-hand experience? It could be fun ... but your odds are slim.

The technique, or some say art, of cross-examining witnesses, and the raising of evidentiary objections, are things that attorneys spend many years learning. That is part of what a litigation attorney can do for you. Those are not things you should attempt on your own, and if you do, your chances of success with your arguments will be very low. This is not an attempt to just give you an evasive answer. This forum is not designed to try to teach someone trial skills or the rules of evidence. It is for general legal questions to assist people in their understanding of their legal options and to aid in making decisions concerning their legal and financial situation. I recommend you do yourself a big favor and consult with and hire a local litigation attorney that can properly represent you in examining the "keeper of records" and any other witnesses and to also properly prepare and argue evidentiary objections on your behalf. If the issues, and dollar amount involved, are worth fighting over at all, you would be much better off having an experienced attorney doing the fighting for you.
